In the crowd, someone shouted, “Is this a show for you to watch? With cigarettes! (Cough, cough!) You might as well keep your hats on…. And there’s someone in a hat! … Get away! You should at least respect the dead!”

Katerina Ivanovna was coughing hard, but her complaints had some effect. The people around her seemed to be a bit scared of her. One by one, the lodgers stepped back into the doorway, feeling a strange mix of satisfaction and sympathy that often happens during an accident, even for those close to the victim.

Outside, voices were heard talking about the hospital and saying they shouldn’t cause a scene here.

“No one should die!” Katerina Ivanovna shouted, rushing to the door to yell at them. But she ran into Madame Lippevechsel, the landlady, who had just heard about the accident and came in to help. She was a very argumentative and careless German woman.

“Oh my God!” she exclaimed, raising her hands. “Your husband was trampled by drunk horses! He needs to go to the hospital! I am the landlady!”

“Amalia Ludwigovna, please remember what you are saying,” Katerina Ivanovna said in a proud tone. She always spoke to the landlady this way to remind her of her place, and even now, she couldn’t help but feel satisfied doing it. “Amalia Ludwigovna…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Katerina Ivanovna confronts the crowd and the landlady about the disrespect shown towards her injured husband, Marmeladov.
